column1: Traralgon (locally ) is a town located in the east of the Latrobe Valley in the Gippsland region of Victoria
column2: Australia. The urban population of Traralgon at the 2016 census was 25
column3: 485. It is the largest and fastest growing city in the greater Latrobe Valley area
column4: which has a population of 74
column5: 170 at June 2016 and is administered by the City of Latrobe.

column1: == Naming ==
The origin of the name Traralgon is uncertain. The name was used for the pastoral lease of the Hobson brothers in 1844
column2: which may have been called Tarra Algon and later changed to Traralgon.The property name is popularly believed to be derived from Gunai language words tarra meaning "river" and algon meaning "little fish". However
column3: these words are not reflected in modern linguists' knowledge of the Gunai language
column4: where
column6: the word for river is wun wun or wurn wurn.

column1: == History ==
Traralgon is situated on the traditional lands of the Indigenous Gunai/Kurnai nation
column2: which includes the lands of the Braiakaulung clan of Bunjil Kraura
column3: who lived to the north of Latrobe River (called Durt'yowan in Gunai language)
column4: as well as the clan of Woollum-Woollum
column5: who lived to the south of the river and were more affiliated with the Brataualung people.Gunai/Kurnai people manufactured stone tools
column8: from silcrete quarries in the Haunted Hills
column9: west of Morwell. Scarred trees and rock sites with axe-grinding grooves are also found in the local area. The Gippsland region was inhabited by the Gunai/Kurnai people for a period in excess of 20
column11: according to evidence of occupation found at the New Guinea II cave near Buchan
column12: Victoria.  In other parts of Victoria evidence of Indigenous occupation has been found for a larger time period

column1: === Expeditions ===
The first non-Indigenous visitors to the area of Traralgon included the party of Count Paweł Strzelecki on their journey from the Snowy Mountains in April 1840
column2: after Strzelecki had named Australia's highest peak as Mount Kosciuszko. Charley Tarra
column3: a Burra Burra man from the NSW town of Taralga
column4: was the Indigenous guide for the party
column5: which included Strzelecki; the New South Wales men James MacArthur and James Riley; and their servants
column6: Irish convict James Nolan and African convict John Rent.The party crossed Latrobe River and travelled along Traralgon Creek to a heavily forested area
column7: where the party was forced to abandon their horses and equipment. The location was commemorated by monument at Traralgon Creek
column9: erected in 1927. The team's rations were reduced to a slice of bacon and a biscuit per day
column10: but Tarra hunted for animals to end their hunger. They traversed the headwaters of Morwell River
column11: before making a difficult journey across the heavily forested mountain range. They reached Anderson's run in Western Port in May 1840
column12: then walked to Melbourne.To honour the men
column13: the mountain range was named the Strzelecki Ranges
column14: part of the forest was named Tarra Valley
column15: later merged into Tarra-Bulga National Park
column16: and the river running from the valley to Port Albert was named Tarra River. Strzelecki named the region as Gipps' Land
column18: in honour of his sponsor NSW Governor George Gipps.In June 1840
column21: John Rutledge and Shoalhaven Indigenous man John Pigeon went on a second expedition to retrieve the lost horses and managed to retrieved one
column22: by travelling through the mountains of West Gippsland
column23: across a path that would roughly trace the present-day Princes Highway. A third expedition was made from Port Albert to Latrobe Valley in March 1841 that included William Brodribb
column25: Norman McLeod and Kirsopp with Tarra as their guide. In June 1841
column26: a fourth expedition was made along the same route by William's brother Albert Brodribb
column28: Dr Edward Barker and four Boon wurrung men.

column1: === Pastoral leases ===
The area around Traralgon was first settled by Europeans in the 1840s. Due to the Latrobe Valley having relatively high rainfall
column2: the land is very fertile
column3: and farming was quickly established. As with much of central and western Gippsland
column4: this was mainly dairy farming. In the Gippsland region between 1840 and 1860
column5: the population of settlers grew from a few to 2
column6: 000 and the recorded Gunai population fell from 2
column7: 000 to a handful.The first Europeans to take land in Traralgon were the brothers Dr Edmund Hobson and Edward Hobson who purchased 19
column9: which they called Traralgon. In April 1844
column10: Edward to a large mob of cattle out from their station near Arthur's Seat to Traralgon arriving two months later. Albert Brodribb and William Bennett started Hazelwood Station in 1844 and the following year James Rintoul had taken a run in Loy Yang and Thomas Gorringe had taken up a run at Maryvale.

column1: === Township established ===
The township was established in the early 1860s
column2: the first Post Office opening on 1 January 1861.In 1877 the railway line from Melbourne was completed with a railway station at Traralgon giving the town a major economic boost.

column1: Traralgon was part of the area administered by the Rosedale Roads Board
column2: before the Shire of Traralgon was established in 1879. In the latter part of the 19th century the Shire grew strongly.

column1: It was not until the 1930s however that Traralgon began to move away from a farming based economy. In 1936 Australian Paper Manufacturers established a paper mill at Maryvale
column2: around 8 kilometres (5 mi) from Traralgon.

column1: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip
column2: Duke of Edinburgh visited on 3 March 1954. The president of the Shire of Traralgon
column3: Cr Clem Little met and welcomed the Queen
column4: who was flown by the Royal Australian Air Force from Sale. She returned to Melbourne by train.In 1960 Traralgon's most famous son Sir Macfarlane Burnet jointly won the Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine.

column1: In 1961 Traralgon formed its own borough
column2: the Borough of Traralgon following a decade of lobbying to separate the urban areas of Traralgon from the Shire.

column1: Traralgon was proclaimed a city in 1964.
The old town hall and mechanics institute were demolished in 1973.Further development resulted from the expansion of the power generation industry following World War II
column2: particularly through the now defunct State Electricity Commission of Victoria. This included large expansions at Yallourn and Hazelwood Power Stations and the construction of the massive Loy Yang Power Station in the 1970s and 1980s.

column1: The first Loy Yang power station was completed in 1985.
An Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) information processing centre was established in the early 1990s
column2: at the time employing around 400 people.

column1: The City of Traralgon and Shire of Traralgon continued a separate existence until they were amalgamated into the Shire of Latrobe in 1994.
Completion of the Loy Yang power stations
column2: extensive voluntary departures from the electricity industry and privatisation of the Victorian electricity industry in the early 1990s had devastating effects on the economy of the Latrobe Valley. Traralgon
column3: with a more diversified economy
column4: suffered to a lesser extent than the neighbouring towns of Morwell and Moe both of which relied almost exclusively on the power stations for their livelihood.

column1: Traralgon grew strongly in the mid 2000s
column2: with a figure of 2.7% making it the largest and fastest growing city in the Latrobe Valley.

column1: === Heritage listings ===
Traralgon contains a number of heritage-listed sites
column2: including:

column1: 161-165 Franklin Street: Traralgon Post Office and Court House
Queens Parade: Traralgon Engine Shed and Turntable
Victory Park
column2: Mill Street: Azarole Hawthorn Tree

column1: == Geography ==

Traralgon is situated on expansive flat land in the Traralgon Creek valley catchment between the Great Dividing Range in the north and the Strzelecki Ranges in the south.  The Traralgon Creek runs through the city's centre and its green belt separates its eastern and western suburban areas.  The urban area is hemmed to the south east by the Loy Yang Open Cut.
=== Urban Structure ===
Traralgon is part of the Latrobe Valley tri-city urban area
column2: a small area of industry and agricultural land separates it from neighbouring Morwell.  Traralgon together with adjacent Morwell forms an urban area with an estimated population of 41
column3: 984 as at June 2018. In the five years prior
column4: the urban area had experienced a modest average annual growth in population of 0.5%. The Traralgon portion the combined Morwell area had a population of 27
column6: also at June 2018. Greater Traralgon includes localities such as Traralgon
column7: the suburb of Traralgon East and the relatively sparsely populated satellite localities of Hazelwood and Traralgon South to the south
column8: and Tyers and Glengarry to the north.

column1: The Traralgon central business district is centred around Seymour and Franklin Streets. An indoor shopping mall called Stockland Traralgon was opened in 1985 as Traralgon Centre Plaza
column2: but renamed after the acquisition by Stockland in 2003. Commercial and light industry sprawl along most of the eastern stretch of the Princes Highway. Notable heritage buildings include the Post Office and Courthouse erected in 1886 and Ryans Hotel erected in 1914
column3: both in Franklin Street.

column1: == Economy ==
The economy is primarily driven by primary industry
column2: natural resources and secondary industry including coal mining
column3: processing and fossil-fuel power generation for the National Electricity Market.  Along with electricity production
column4: Traralgon benefits from the mining for oil and natural gas in the nearby Bass Strait fields.

column1: A significant forestry industry operates including logging of both plantation and natural forest timber
column2: The largest paper mill in Australia is located nearby in Maryvale and provides local employment for over 2000 people.

column1: The local agriculture industry is involved in the production of wool and dairy products
column2: as well as vegetable growing.

column1: The tertiary sector of the economy is also important for employment with major government administration offices for the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC)
column2: the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS)
column3: the Department of Environment
column4: Land
column7: and the Environment Protection Authority Victoria (EPA).

column1: == Education ==
Traralgon features a number of primary and secondary schools
column2: including state
column3: catholic and independent schools.

column1: The local primary schools include Grey Street Primary School (formerly Traralgon Primary School)
column2: Kosciuszko Street Primary School
column3: Liddiard Road Primary School
column4: Stockdale Road Primary School
column7: Chairo Christian School (formerly Flinders Christian Community College) and St Pauls Anglican Grammar School. St Paul's Anglican Grammar School and Chairo Christian School are also secondary schools. In addition Traralgon has the Latrobe Special Developmental School catering for students from 4.5 to 18 years of age with an intellectual and physical disability.

column1: The local government secondary school
column2: Traralgon College
column3: has two campuses
column4: the junior campus (years 7–9) located on Liddiard Rd in Traralgon's east
column5: with the senior campus (years 10–12) on Grey St in Traralgon's west. There is also a Catholic secondary school
column6: Lavalla Catholic College. Lavalla has two campuses in Traralgon's West end
column7: and a third campus in Newborough
column10: neighbours Traralgon College's senior campus on Grey St. The senior campus
column12: is located in Kosciuszko St. Chairo Christian School on Liddiard Rd is a P– 8 school.

column1: Flinders began its first year as Chario in 2018.
A number of Traralgon families also send their children to the three independent Anglican grammar schools in the region
column2: two of which are about 40 minutes drive from Traralgon: St. Paul's Anglican Grammar School
column3: which has a campus in Traralgon as well as Warragul
column4: or Gippsland Grammar School in Sale.

column1: TAFE and University education is also available within the region. Traralgon is a 15-minute drive from Federation University Australia's Gippsland Campus
column2: located in the neighbouring town of Churchill. Traralgon is also home to one of a number of campuses for the region's TAFE provider
column3: Federation Training.

column1: === Sport ===
Australian rules football is popular.  There are two senior clubs
column2: the Traralgon Maroons (which briefly competed in the Victorian Football League between 1996–1997) currently competing in the Gippsland Football League and Traralgon-Tyers United competing in the North Gippsland Football League. There is also a junior league
column3: Traralgon and District Junior Football League
column4: with most games played from the West End Sporting Complex.

column1: Cricket is also popular
column2: with a local league
column3: the Traralgon and District Cricket Association (TDCA) operating.

column1: Soccer is represented by two clubs - Traralgon City and Traralgon Olympians - who both play in the Latrobe Valley Soccer League. The Victorian regional leagues are the eighth level of soccer in Victoria
column2: and the ninth nationally. The home grounds are Harold Preston Reserve and Harold Preston Park respectively.

column1: There is a local basketball league
column2: the Traralgon Basketball Association with a stadium at the Traralgon Sports Complex. The Traralgon Sports Stadium played host to preliminary round games of the Basketball competition during the 2006 Commonwealth Games which were held in Melbourne.

column1: The local baseball team is the Traralgon Redsox. www.traralgon.baseball.com.au
Traralgon has a horse racing club
column2: the Latrobe Valley Racing Club
column3: which schedules two race meetings a year including the Cup meeting in December.The Traralgon Greyhound Racing Club holds regular meetings at Glenview Park.Golfers play at the course of the Traralgon Golf Club on the Princes Highway.The Traralgon Harriers are a running club that runs 5 or 6 km races every Thursday night and also organise Victoria's oldest marathon
column4: the Traralgon Marathon

column1: The Latrobe Valley Cycling club hold road and track racing events on most weeks throughout the year.
Traralgon Pistol Club and Traralgon small bore rifle Club also located in the town with a healthy membership at both clubs.
=== Entertainment ===
The entertainment precinct which spans Kay
column2: Grey and Franklin Streets attracts people from surrounding towns to several nightclubs
column3: bars and restaurants located there.

column1: == Local media ==
=== Newspapers ===
The twice weekly Latrobe Valley Express newspaper is delivered to all homes on Monday and Thursday nights
column2: in Traralgon
column3: Morwell and Moe. Smaller
column4: weekly papers the Traralgon Journal
column6: along with the Morwell and Churchill Advertiser are delivered to all homes on Monday nights with The Latrobe Valley Express. The Traralgon Record newspaper has been digitised from 1886 to 1932 as part of the Australian Newspapers Digitisation Program.Melbourne Newspapers such as The Weekly Times
column7: The Age and the Herald Sun and national newspapers like The Australian and the Australian Financial Review are also available.

column1: === Television ===
The three main commercial television networks (Seven
column2: Nine and Ten) are all re-broadcast in the Latrobe Valley by their regional affiliates – Prime7 (Seven)
column3: WIN Television (Ten) and Nine Traralgon. The area was the first in Australia to receive its own regional television station
column4: GLV-10 Gippsland (now Southern Cross Nine)

column1: Of the three main commercial networks:
WIN Television airs a half-hour local WIN News each weeknight at 6pm
column2: produced from a newsroom in the city and broadcast from studios in Wollongong.

column1: Southern Cross Nine airs a regional Victoria edition of Nine News from Melbourne each weeknight at 6pm
column2: featuring opt-outs for Gippsland.

column1: Prime7 airs short local news and weather updates throughout the day
column2: produced and broadcast from its Canberra studios.Most Melbourne channels (Seven
column3: Nine and Ten) can also be received in digital in Traralgon with a suitable roof-top antenna.

column1: New channels broadcast by the commercial networks in addition to the ones listed above are available on the digital service called Freeview (Australia) to viewers in Traralgon and the Gippsland/Latrobe Valley region. These channels include One HD
column2: Eleven
column3: 7Two
column4: 7mate

column1: Both national public broadcasters
column2: the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (including channels ABC1
column3: ABC2
column4: ABC3 & ABC News 24) and Special Broadcasting Service (including SBS One & SBS Two)
column5: are also broadcast to the Latrobe Valley.

column1: Subscription television service Foxtel (previously Austar until 2014) is available via satellite.
=== Radio ===
There are two radio stations with studios located in Traralgon – TRFM and Gold 1242
column2: both owned by Ace Radio. The FM station is broadcast along with the television channels from Mount Tassie while Gold 1242 is broadcast from an AM transmitter near Sale. Warragul radio stations Star FM and 3GG also service this region. Most Australian Broadcasting Corporation stations are rebroadcast locally and available in Traralgon
column3: along with 774 ABC Melbourne which is able to be received directly from Melbourne.

column1: == Transport ==

Road transport and the motor vehicle is the main form of transport. The Princes Highway runs through the city and close to the CBD which received heavy regional traffic (although a Traralgon Bypass road is undergoing planning).  The Hyland Highway also originates at Traralgon.

Rail transport includes both passenger rail and freight rail. The city's only station is Traralgon railway station which is on the Orbost railway line. Both the Traralgon V/Line rail service and the Bairnsdale V/Line rail service stop there. Traralgon is currently the terminus for VLocity trains with a two way hourly service. Travel time to Melbourne Flinders Street ranges at approximately 109 minutes during peak travel times. Victoria's electronic ticketing system
column2: Myki
column3: was implemented on rail services between Traralgon and Melbourne on 8 July 2013.Latrobe Valley Buslines provides local services around Traralgon and other cities in the Latrobe Valley.

column1: Latrobe Valley Airport is located close to Traralgon in nearby Morwell and provides general aviation.
Traralgon has a minimal bicycle infrastructure
column2: with few segregated cycle facilities.  An exception is the 63-kilometer-long Gippsland Plains Rail Trail which connects Traralgon to Stratford via Cowwarr
column3: Heyfield
column4: Tinamba and Maffra.

column1: === Climate ===
Traralgon experiences an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb). Nights in Traralgon are about 2 °C colder than in Melbourne
